awd_titl_txt: Inference in High-Dimensional Linear Models: Methods, Theory, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical inferential methods are used to answer questions in a variety of modern science disciplines. For example, in medical studies, whether the treatment effect varies by different individuals and which treatment procedure will be recommended to a future patient given his or her baseline information; in genomics, whether different traits share common genetic etiology and how gene expression levels are regulated by genetic variants. For these complex studies, high-dimensional linear models have become ubiquitous to approximate the data generating mechanism and extract useful information. Despite significant advances on estimation, inference problems in high-dimensional linear models have been far less understood, from both methodological and theoretical perspectives. In this project, the investigator plans to address the methodological and theoretical challenges of high-dimensional statistical inference problems, including confidence interval construction and hypothesis testing, and apply the developed methods to answer important scientific questions encountered in genomics and health studies.                                
                        
                
The research objective is to construct confidence intervals and conduct hypothesis testing in a simultaneous consideration of multiple sparse high-dimensional linear models, which are important in answering scientific questions encountered in a wide range of applications. Specifically, the investigator will tackle statistical inference problems by the following means: (1) constructing confidence intervals for functionals of multiple regression vectors and conduct significance tests for groups of variables; (2) testing the existence of heterogeneity in treatment effects and compare efficacy of different treatment procedures for a specific individual; (3) studying multiple testing procedures for a large number of functionals; and (4) applying the developed inferential procedures and collaborate with researchers in genomics and epidemiology to answer important scientific questions about genetic relatedness network and personalized treatment comparison through analyzing large-scale data sets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
High-dimensional data analysis emerges in various scientific fields, including biology, medicine, economics, and signal processing. The availability of high-dimensional data, whose dimension can be much larger than the sample size, has created both challenges and opportunities for statisticians. The research objective of this proposal is to construct confidence intervals and conduct hypothesis testing in consideration of various high-dimensional models. Specifically, the PI has devised new methods and theories for the following high-dimensional inference problems,

 

(1) We propose a novel semi-supervised inference method for the explained variance in high dimensions and investigate the benefit of using the unlabeled data in terms of the method and theory. 

(2) We study the individualized treatment selection by leveraging a large number of baseline covariates. We devise a novel biased correction method to make inferences for the individualized treatment effect in high dimensions.

(3) We propose new inference methods for the rate of change in the high-dimensional sparse additive model. 

(4) We consider the setting with many variables that are confounded with a few hidden confounders. We propose a novel doubly debiased lasso estimator to make inferences for the high-dimensional effects.

(5) We study the group inference problem in a high-dimensional linear model, and the method is applied to conduct a group significance test, hierarchical testing, the test of interaction, and inference for local heritability. 

(6) We consider inference in high-dimensional generalized linear models with binary outcomes and propose novel weighted debiased estimators. We also establish the fundamental limit of confidence interval construction in the high-dimensional generalized linear model. 

 

Throughout the above projects, we analyze the large-scale data sets in genomics, health studies, and economics with the proposed inferential procedures and collaborate with researchers to answer critical scientific questions in genomics and epidemiology. We also developed a publicly available R packages SIHR to implement a series of proposed high-dimensional inference methods, including the method proposed in (1), (2), (5), and (6). The codes for implementing (3) and (4) are also made publicly available on the GitHub webpage. 

 

 

Intellectual Merit. High-dimensional statistical inference is of importance to answer scientific questions in applications. However, there is a lack of methods and theory for statistical inference in various high-dimensional models, including both confidence interval construction and hypothesis testing. The statistical methodologies devised in the current grant will advance the understanding of statistical inference in a collection of high-dimensional models. Additionally, the results obtained in this grant contribute to the development of the intersection research operations between high-dimensional statistics and causal inference. Furthermore, the obtained results connect the high-dimensional statistics and the machine learning research topics. 

 

Broader Impacts. The collaboration with researchers in biostatistics and epidemiology answered critical scientific questions and advanced statistical methodologies applied in genomics and health studies. The applications in genomics and health studies are essential to society, where the solutions are instrumental in understanding both the biological processes and disease-related genomic processes. In particular, this proposal is among the first to rigorously and carefully study the genetic relatedness network in the statistical framework, and, in addition, this network idea has been broadly used to visualize genetic architectures. The hypothesis testing approach for personalized treatment selection plays an essential role in studying personalized medicine. We have published three user-friendly software and created ten open-source codes on the Github Webpage. These activities have significant impacts on health care and make essential contributions to society. The PI has disseminated the obtained results in more than 20 conference talks and department seminars to enhance understanding of the results in statistics and other scientific disciplines. The PI has integrated the research output into teaching through developing a new Ph.D. course at the home university. The research problems in this grant are used to train three Ph.D. students and a few master students in interdisciplinary disciplines of statistics, biostatistics, and epidemiology.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Zijian Guo
